posts.name: Sebastian Pacheco
posts.cooked: Hello, I was wondering if anyone knew of how to calculate if a load through a steel gear was appropriate for the material? I am afraid that the torque transmitted through the gears may be too much for them to handle, but I don’t know the appropriate calculations for it. I have been using JVN, and a picture of the gear ratio is below as well as a picture of the CAD.

posts.name: Sebastian Pacheco
posts.cooked: For clarification, it is two neos driving 3 5:1 MAXPlanetary Stages into a 90 Degree gearbox, and that drives a 28T 20DP Steel Gear which then drives a 56T Steel Gear that shares an axle with the other side of the mechanism, with the identical motor and gear setup. This is to drive the arm shown downwards and push the chain further down into the robot, lifting the robot higher in the air.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453

posts.name: Sebastian Pacheco
posts.cooked: That was put there by a mentor I got the spreadsheet from, perhaps you know them. Team 179

I don’t know how to caluate the strength of gear teeth yet because its complicated, however, it is most likely not your weakest link. The hex shaft powering this gear will very likely fail before the gears fail (if it will even fail at all) because hex shafts are in the grand scheme of things, very weak and there’s isn’t that much of a reducton in between the hex shaft and the final output, and finding the stresses in a shaft is a lot easier than finding the stresses in a gear.

posts.name: Sebastian Pacheco
posts.cooked: Would you say that even a steel hex shaft would be weaker than the steal gears?

posts.name: Brendan Manning
posts.cooked:
See the posts in this thread from @EricH

Bevel Gear Torque Ratings General Forum

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: May I recommend coloring your black components as grey in cad to make the details more visible?

posts.name: Sebastian Pacheco
posts.cooked: This may help, it is a better angle as well.

Much weaker, steel isn’t magically strong and 0.5 hex is not particularly strong shaft profile in general. With how this climb is set up, I’d expect the shaft to yield well before the robot leaves the ground.

posts.name: Sebastian Pacheco
posts.cooked: Alright, I might have to switch to a stronger shaft size then, thanks for the advice.
I would look at WCPs Spline XL shaft for this, it is bigger and stronger shaft and they make steel gears you can put over it.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
ThatMechanicalDude:

Think about it this way: From your calc, your setup is capable of applying 575lbs at the end of each 10 inch arm when stalled. To achieve that force at a 10 inch radius the gear tooth at a radius of 1.4 inch will be seeing a load of 4100lbs (assuming you haven’t already shared off your hex shaft) In other words, don’t ever stall this at full power. It won’t survive.

If it is never stalled or shock loaded and each arm only ever sees a maximum weight of 1 robot (~150lb), the the gear tooth would still be experiencing over 1000lbs which might be survivable for some amount of time, but I guarantee not for long.

posts.name: Sebastian Pacheco
posts.cooked: Thanks for the warning, but I am curious what calculation did you do to get to the 4100 pounds at the gear tooth? I want to be able to play with it so I can see what the minimum size of the smaller gear should be.

Domtech:

From your calc, your setup is capable of applying 575lbs at the end of each 10 inch arm when stalled.

Domtech:

(assuming you haven’t already shared off your hex shaft)

And using the shaft torsion equations under these loading conditions, the shaft would experience a shear stress of 1.5 GPa from just the torsion alone which is several times past the stress required to break hex shafts. And that’s ignoring the additional bending, traverse shear, and bearing stresses caused the loading conditions.

The best way to power a climb in these cases is to use a winch that pulls a rope near the end of the spool which avoids the need of excessive reductions.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
ThatMechanicalDude:

I am curious what calculation did you do to get to the 4100 pounds at the gear tooth?

All I did was take the stall load output from the calc you posted and multiply it by 10/1.4 to find the force at the other end of the lever arm.

Here is what it looks like when it is holding one robot weight and no more:

ThatMechanicalDude:

I want to be able to play with it so I can see what the minimum size of the smaller gear should be.

Easy way to check the gear load quickly is to set the arm length in the calculator to the radius of the gear attached to it. I don’t actually have a good number for what a safe load is. When I googled it, the AI regurgitated my own words from this very thread: Thank you Google, very cool.

This calculator tells me that for a 3/8" wide 4140 steel gear you should target a tooth load under 200lbs although I don’t know how conservative it is being:

My recommendation is to get some 1/8" dyneema/UHMWPE rope and do what was suggested here:

Alex_Y:

use a winch that pulls a rope near the end of the spool which avoids the need of excessive reductions.

Here is a very quick way to implement it: image 807×467 87.3 KB You could probably also take out a gearbox stage (or two) and come out having saved weight.

image 807×467 87.3 KB

image 807×467 87.3 KB

posts.name: Rocky
posts.cooked:
The reply from Domtech above is truly awsome, building ontop of Domtech’s idea a bit: image 1093×631 47 KB I think if using a winch, you might need a force to pulling the climbers out for easy deployment.(in greed arrow) It can be surgical tubing, although I’m not sure about the optimal way to implement this

image 1093×631 47 KB

image 1093×631 47 KB

This is team 254’s climb, similar idea: image 1187×784 215 KB Use something less powerful to extend out the climber(in A, looks like a dampner in this pic), and use something powerful to pull the climber down (in B, a winch).

image 1187×784 215 KB

image 1187×784 215 KB

For short, u need something to extend the climbers out, before pulling it down with a winch

Also more, make the 90 degree gearbox on both sides co-axle if you want both climbers deploy at the same time. BUT: U may not want this, as if you climb from the side and go for harmony, the chain is higher at the side and lower at the middle

posts.name: Sebastian Pacheco
